Most people can understand the results that you show them, but it's very unlikely that most people can comprehend what it takes to achieve the results you show them.
This might be a reason why the greatest of  leaders must show compassion. Most people might not ever achieve what you will, and that’s okay, but that doesn’t make them less than you.
We all have our path. Follow yours. Greatness is greatness, and maybe not everyone will understand your greatness.
That’s okay - just keep going. Your own greatness is just as important as the one who gets the most credit for it. No one ever achieves anything that humanity remembers worthwhile alone.
It's a new year! I am so thankful for my LinkedIn community and I wish every single one of you a blessed year with tremendous momentum!
If you're managing a team in 2018, you might find the following pointers a little useful.
1. Working when sick is not a sign of commitment.
2. Someone asking for a raise is not a sign of entitlement.
3. Responding to e-mails on your day off is not a sign of dedication.
4. Employees working over the weekend is not a sign of devotion.
5. Calls and meetings outside of working hours is not a sign of desire.
Allowing all of the above to happen is the easiest path to having unhappy employees, high turnover and poor morale.
We win when teams do all of the above out of a sense of responsibility and duty. We lose when they do it out of a sense of fear.
